bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 74 (Tuesday, May 2, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. STEIL:H.R. 3070.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article 1 Section 8The single subject of this legislation is:Requires the President, before providing specifiedsanctions relief to an Iranian person that is on the list ofspecially designated nationals and blocked persons, tocertify to Congress that the person has ceased involvement interrorism[Page H2128]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

summary.text:
No Sanctions Relief for Terrorists Act

This bill prohibits granting a waiver or license to conduct transactions with certain Iranian individuals and entities unless the President certifies to Congress that the individual or entity has ceased involvement in terrorism.

The bill's prohibition applies to Iranian individuals and entities included on the January 20, 2021, list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons pursuant to Executive Order 13224. (U.S. persons are usually prohibited from transacting with individuals or entities on this list, also called the SDN list, although a license or waiver can allow transactions that would otherwise be prohibited.)

bill.title: No Sanctions Relief for Terrorists Act

item.title: No Sanctions Relief for Terrorists Act
No Sanctions Relief for Terrorists Act
To prohibit the issuance of licenses or other waivers from sanctions imposed pursuant to certain authorities relating to the conduct of Iran, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
